verses.text: Then King of Egypt gathered together a great army, as numerous as the sand on the shore, with many ships; he sought by deceit to take control over Alexander’s kingdom.
verses.comment: Ptolemy VI uses treachery, warning of political intrigue common in the ancient Near East.

verses.text: He came into Syria peacefully, and the people opened the city gates to him; they welcomed him as Alexander had ordered.
verses.comment: The peaceful approach masks his intention, emphasizing the need for discernment.

verses.text: But as soon as Ptolemy entered the cities, he stationed troops in every one.
verses.comment: Installation of garrisons represents claiming authority, paralleling other ancient conquests (Judges 4:1–5).

verses.text: When he approached Azotus, they showed him the temple of Dagon, destroyed and the city, burned and ruined, with bodies thrown everywhere and those slaughtered in battle; for they had prepared the king.
verses.comment: Reference to Dagon signals God's victory over pagan idols (1 Sam. 5:1–5).

verses.text: They told the king what Jonathan had done, desiring to credit him; and the king praised Jonathan.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s reputation among gentile rulers recalls Joseph’s favor with Pharaoh (Gen. 41:39–41).

verses.text: Jonathan met the king in Joppa with great ceremony, and they greeted one another and stayed there.
verses.comment: Joppa was a significant strategic port; the greeting shows diplomatic relations.

verses.text: Jonathan traveled with the king to the river called Eleutherus; then he returned to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: This river marked a boundary of territory and power in ancient Syria.

verses.text: But King Alexander heard what was happening and became troubled; so Ptolemy returned to Antioch.
verses.comment: Alexander’s anxiety reveals unstable kingship, underscoring divine providence above all earthly rulers.

verses.text: King Alexander’s reaction was one of trouble; and Ptolemy withdrew to Antioch.
verses.comment: Antioch, as a key center, symbolizes human ambition and the frailty of power.

verses.text: King Ptolemy wore a crown in Egypt, and his daughter Cleopatra wore another; they paraded through Antioch in great splendor.
verses.comment: Public display of royalty emphasizes human pride, which the prophets often critique (Isa. 14:13–15).

verses.text: Alexander’s intentions turned hostile against Ptolemy.
verses.comment: Political alliances are fleeting; true unity requires divine intervention.

verses.text: Ptolemy seized the coastal cities up to Seleucia by sea and established garrisons in all, taking advantage of his designs against Alexander.
verses.comment: Occupation of strategic locations prefigures universal authority, a theme fulfilled spiritually (Ps. 2:8).

verses.text: He turned against Alexander, sending envoys to Demetrius to say: ‘Come, let us make a covenant, and I will give you my daughter whom Alexander married, and you shall reign over your father’s kingdom.
verses.comment: Political intrigue—marriage as power—mirrors biblical episodes like Solomon’s alliances (1 Kings 3:1).

verses.text: I regret having given my daughter to Alexander; his plots against me have become clear.’
verses.comment: Repudiation of alliances reflects instability in worldly power structures.

verses.text: Ptolemy withdrew his daughter from Alexander and gave her to Demetrius, breaking relations with Alexander.
verses.comment: Reversal of marriage alliances suggests the fleeting nature of worldly foundations.

verses.text: Ptolemy turned against Alexander, exposing his hostility, ending their friendship.
verses.comment: The betrayal foreshadows similar events in salvation history, e.g., Judas (Matt. 26:14–16).

verses.text: Then Ptolemy entered Antioch and placed the crowns on his own head—of Asia and Egypt.
verses.comment: Dual crowns denote aspiration for universal dominion, an imperfect echo of the King of kings (Rev. 19:16).

verses.text: King Alexander fled to Arabia to seek protection, and King Zabdiel of Arabia killed him and sent his head to Ptolemy.
verses.comment: The decapitation recalls Herod and John the Baptist (Mark 6:27–29), illustrating earthly retribution.

verses.text: But Ptolemy died three days later, and the men in the strongholds he had placed perished.
verses.comment: Rapid reversal underscores the fragile nature of human power.

verses.text: Demetrius became king in the one hundred and sixty-seventh year.
verses.comment: Precise dating presents historical reliability and the sovereignty of divine providence guiding the course of kingdoms.

verses.text: In those days, certain lawless men from Israel revolted against Jonathan and accused him before Demetrius, prompting unrest.
verses.comment: Internal opposition references divisions among God’s people, paralleling the rebellion against Moses (Num. 16:1–3).

verses.text: But King Demetrius sent a message to Jonathan: ‘I will not listen to those who speak against you; instead, appoint yourself as high priest and governor over Israel.’
verses.comment: Royal appointment reinforces the legitimacy of established priestly succession and authority, a foundation for continuity.

verses.text: So Jonathan wore the sacred vestments and ruled as governor.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s wearing of priestly garments signifies sanctification, connecting with sacramental authority and leadership.

verses.text: Jonathan gathered together the elders of Israel and examined those who had stirred up trouble. He dismissed them and returned to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Jonathan exercises discipline in the community, echoing prophetic calls to purge evil (Deut. 19:19).

verses.text: But the army of Demetrius was often in revolt against him; he could not remain secure on his throne.
verses.comment: Continual rebellion shows the disorder of earthly kingdoms contrasted against God’s order.

verses.text: So Demetrius called Jonathan, saying, ‘Come with your experienced men and help me; we must bring peace to my kingdom.’
verses.comment: Invitation to Jonathan shows the value and necessity of God’s people in restoring order.

verses.text: Jonathan went up to Antioch with three thousand men, and Demetrius welcomed him.
verses.comment: The size of the retinue again points to strength and unity among the faithful.

verses.text: When the men of the city assembled inside, Demetrius ordered Jonathan and his men to take control.
verses.comment: Entrusting the city to Jonathan implies delegated authority and trust.

verses.text: Jonathan expelled those rebelling, and the city and its inhabitants were pacified.
verses.comment: Restoring peace reflects the role of leadership and mediation among God’s people.

verses.text: When Demetrius saw the city’s peace, he fulfilled all of Jonathan’s promises and honored him before all his advisors.
verses.comment: Recognition from rulers previews fulfillment in the Messiah’s exaltation (Phil. 2:9–11).

verses.text: He made Jonathan’s brother Simon commander from the borders of Tyre to the Egyptians.
verses.comment: Simon’s appointment expands the family’s role and stewardship, an echo of apostolic succession.

verses.text: Jonathan asked Demetrius to exempt Judea and the three districts—Samaria, Galilee, and Ptolemais—from taxation.
verses.comment: Exemption signals distinct status for God’s people, as promised to Abraham (Gen. 12:2–3).

verses.text: Demetrius wrote to Jonathan this letter: ‘King Demetrius to Jonathan and the Jewish people, peace.
verses.comment: The formal greeting bestows dignity and recognition of Jonathan’s leadership.

verses.text: We grant you exemption, as you requested, from taxes on all sacred and divine things, and on salt, and crowns owed to us.
verses.comment: Exemptions on sacred duties recall God’s provisions for priests (Num. 18:8–12).

verses.text: And we grant you control over the city of Ptolemais, and its lands and revenues, for you.
verses.comment: Control over cities underscores authority and stewardship, encouraged in biblical kingship.

verses.text: As for those now considered guilty or liable in our kingdom, you are responsible for their judgment and pardon.
verses.comment: Granting judicial authority to Jonathan points to mediation in leadership, suggesting divine justice and mercy.

verses.text: All these grants we execute for your people; write them on public tablets in your holy places so all may see.
verses.comment: Public recording in the temple hints at the visible witness of God’s covenant, seen throughout Scripture.

verses.text: So Jonathan and the Jewish people received favors from Demetrius and kept them in their possession.
verses.comment: Reception of favor illustrates providence, but also the responsibility of stewardship.

verses.text: But Trypho, a former supporter of Alexander, gathered his army and became hostile to Demetrius.
verses.comment: Trypho’s rebellion is a further reminder of the instability of earthly powers.

verses.text: He found Antiochus, Alexander’s young son, and proclaimed him king.
verses.comment: The elevation of a child as king is reminiscent of Joash’s coronation (2 Kings 11:12).

verses.text: Trypho amassed many troops and fought Demetrius, who fled.
verses.comment: Military strife foreshadows many instances of exile and return, preparing for fulfillment in restoration.

verses.text: Trypho sent envoys to Jonathan, saying: ‘Come; I will make peace and give you great honor, for I am returning Alexander’s son as king.’
verses.comment: Promises of peace are routinely deceptive, warning of the necessity to seek truth.

verses.text: He promised to make Jonathan and his troops honored in the king’s service, as if they were friends.
verses.comment: Worldly friendship may be fleeting; Jesus teaches of deeper spiritual friendship (John 15:13–15).

verses.text: So Jonathan trusted Trypho and sent troops to him in Syria. He traveled with Trypho without suspecting any evil.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s trust parallels incidents where innocence faces treachery, echoing Daniel (Dan. 6:22).

verses.text: But he left behind two thousand men and his equipment, and went with Trypho to Ptolemais. Trypho closed the gates and captured Jonathan.
verses.comment: Deception here foreshadows the suffering servant and betrayal motifs throughout Scripture.

verses.text: All Jonathan’s men outside cried out for Jonathan to be freed. They raged and prepared for battle.
verses.comment: The suffering of the leader for his people anticipates Christ’s sacrificial leadership.

verses.text: When Trypho saw their readiness, he was afraid. He went to Jonathan, imprisoned, and promised to let him go if he sent away his men.
verses.comment: Trypho's fear suggests God’s providence in delivering His people, as in Esther (Esther 7:10).

verses.text: Jonathan obeyed and sent his men away. Trypho did not free him, but instead seized him again.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s vulnerability points to the theme of faithful endurance amidst suffering.

verses.text: Trypho sent troops and cavalry into Galilee and the Great Plain to destroy Jonathan's men.
verses.comment: Targeting Galilee highlights its biblical significance as a place of messianic activity.

verses.text: But Jonathan’s men sensed danger and regrouped; they escaped, returning home safely.
verses.comment: Rescue of the faithful alludes to God’s protection of his remnant.

verses.text: Trypho seized Jerusalem and the mountaintop fortress, but he fortified it strongly.
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s fortification recalls its spiritual and historical meaning as the city of God.

verses.text: Trypho sent armed men and supplies into the fortress and took control.
verses.comment: Physical control over Jerusalem's strongholds points to deeper spiritual battles for every believer.

verses.text: He imprisoned the city’s leaders and demanded tribute. He sent soldiers to keep watch.
verses.comment: Tribute and oppression reflect worldly domination, instigating longing for deliverance.

verses.text: Trypho pressed Simon to send silver and gold, and also Jonathan’s sons as hostages to Ptolemais.
verses.comment: Hostages symbolize the cost of leadership and the sacrificial responsibility demanded of those set apart.

verses.text: He claimed: ‘If I am not given them, Jonathan will be killed.’
verses.comment: Threats crystallize the reality of power struggles and the plight of the just.

verses.text: Simon dispatched all required silver and gold, but did not send Jonathan’s sons, fearing deception.
verses.comment: Simon’s caution reflects wisdom commended in Proverbs (Prov. 4:7).

verses.text: Trypho attempted to assault and capture Simon, but Simon’s forces protected him.
verses.comment: Simon’s rescue suggests God’s providential care of righteous leaders.

verses.text: Trypho, angered, returned to the city and killed Jonathan.
verses.comment: Jonathan’s martyrdom prefigures the suffering and death of faithful servants, pointing toward Christ’s own sacrifice.

verses.text: Simon took the body of Jonathan and buried him in the city of his ancestors.
verses.comment: Honorable burial reflects faith in the resurrection and continuity of God’s promises.

verses.text: The people mourned deeply for Jonathan, and all Israel wept for many days.
verses.comment: Mourning for the righteous is biblical (2 Sam. 1:12), and hints at the Church’s remembrance of saints.

verses.text: Simon built a high monument over Jonathan’s tomb with polished stone to the honor of their line.
verses.comment: Monument-building recalls memorial stones in Israel’s history (Josh. 4:20).

verses.text: Trypho ruled harshly and oppressed the land.
verses.comment: Tyranny stirs longing for a just King, as predicted by the prophets.

verses.text: Simon came against Trypho and took control of the territory of Joppa.
verses.comment: Simon’s conquest emphasizes the perseverance and eventual vindication of God’s faithful.

verses.text: He sent out guards, fortified the city, restored its walls and gates.
verses.comment: Restoration of fortifications underscores the need for spiritual as well as physical protection.

verses.text: Simon drove away Trypho from the city, and Trypho retreated to Gaza.
verses.comment: Driving away enemies depicts God championing his people’s cause.

verses.text: Simon pursued Trypho until Gaza, but Trypho escaped.
verses.comment: Perseverance even in incomplete victory encourages steadfastness in faith.

verses.text: Simon established rule over the region from Joppa to Gaza, liberating many towns.
verses.comment: Simon’s liberation prefigures and symbolizes greater deliverance to come.

verses.text: He helped rebuild the towns and returned them to the Jews.
verses.comment: The restoration of towns can be interpreted spiritually as the restoration of souls to righteousness.

verses.text: Simon lived in peace, establishing justice and prosperity for his people.
verses.comment: Simon’s establishment of peace and justice brings to mind messianic prophecies (Isa. 9:6–7).

verses.text: All Israel recognized Simon’s leadership. They loved him and respected his rule.
verses.comment: Universal recognition echoes the ideal of unity and visible order among God’s people.

verses.text: Simon renewed the covenant, and all former enemies sought peace with him.
verses.comment: Renewing covenant reflects the continuous invitation by God to deeper relationship, as established throughout salvation history.

verses.text: Simon grew old, honored everywhere; his leadership brought prosperity and order.
verses.comment: Leadership brings blessing, prefiguring the fullness of God’s kingdom through generations.

verses.text: The nation continued in peace, many years, under Simon’s rule.
verses.comment: Prolonged peace is a foretaste of the eschatological promise found in the prophets.

verses.text: All the deeds of Simon, his wars, rule, acts of heroism, and rebuilding of cities—are recorded in the annals of his reign.
verses.comment: Records of heroic deeds witness to the preservation of memory among God’s people, pointing to the tradition of remembrance and the continuity of faithful leadership.
